author: sky.cactus
content: For the first, this hurts anonymity because now transactions are fairly strongly linked to an origin.

author: pipermerriam
content: In effect, this is how transaction gossip already works.  A node publishes a list list hashes that they have available.  The receiving node requests the transactions they are interested in from the published hashes.

author: pipermerriam
content: The thing that's missing from the current system is something to avoid flooding light nodes with too many transactions.

author: ryanleeschneider
content: right but for the tx to actually propagate it has to be replicated to the mempool of all the intermediaries since they need the tx body to reply w/ if their peer is interested in any particular hash.

author: ryanleeschneider
content: I'd argue that _most_ nodes want to avoid this flooding, not just light nodes.  Unless you're a miner or doing analysis of the mempool do you really want to have the whole mempool in your node, or are you just offering those mempool resources as a public good because thats what the protocol currently requires?

author: pipermerriam
content: Exactly the hard problem hiding inside of this

author: pipermerriam
content: The ideal solution we should look for is one that allows the light nodes to still contribute to transaction gossip in some meaningful way.  Something where nodes can specify their *limits* for gossip and only the nodes with an intrinsic interest in holding the full mempool do so.  Assuming there is such an architecture, it allows the altruistic contributions of a large number of nodes to spread out the responsibility of managing the gossip of the whole pool, significantly lowers the very heavy burden that regular full nodes carry, and still facilitates miners and others interested in the full pool to do their job.

author: pipermerriam
content:
An idealized homogeneous pool needs:

- DOS mitigation
- Amplification mitigation
- Proofs against nonce and balance for stateless validation
- Some mechanism to deal with proofs becoming invalid and to update them so that stateless nodes can invalidate the corresponding transactions.
- The ability for individual nodes to constrain their responsibilities so that low resource devices can contribute.

But alternativesly, a solution that allows light nodes to "inject" transactions into the main pool by some sort of benevolent bridging could also work fine and is probably simpler.  Such a network doesn't need to care as much about gossip and updating proofs

author: pipermerriam
content: It would be more about ensuring that a transaction flows towards the exit nodes that bridge into the main gossip network.

author: sky.cactus
content: :laying-awake-in-bed-thought: full nodes pass proofs back light clients when the light client gossips a bad transaction to the full node.  This would allow the light client to recognize when it is being fed bad transactions from another peer and (if it keeps happening) drop a bad peer.

author: sky.cactus
